Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 10-15 hours
2 hours, midterm and final took longer
About 1 hour
18 hours.
2 for readings, 6 when working on protocol and final paper
Varied from 0-15

AP- Most weeks very little, at the beginning of the semester when I had more time I attempted to do all the readings but this slipped as time went on. 
Probably 30 mins per week most weeks.

However this was balanced with the huge amount of work I put in for the two assignments- the protocol and main systematic review. I would say I put 40+ hours into the final systematic review.
2hrs
10 hours
2-4, much more when working on final project
less than 10 hours
On regular weeks only a few - around the midterm project and final upwards of 20+ and 30+ respectively
2 hours per week

for assignments- 5/week
for readings- 2/week
4 hours
I spent about an hour a week outside the classroom but spent a large portion of time toward the end of the semester.
Excellent!

Overall I felt that this was a good course. I think the material covered was interesting. I think the structure of the class could be improved. The only checkpoint we had on the progress of our systematic review was the midterm. I think the course could have more check-in points where you physically have to hand something in so that you stay on top of everything. The process is complicated and I think being able to get feedback as you go would be helpful.

The professor has a great background knowledge in Medicine. The project is not "phishing". The class is something real and useful. I do think we need more courses for advance meta-analysis such as network meta-analysis, meta-regression.

Good course that teaches a really useful skill in research. Lectures are slightly unfocused and felt sometimes irrelevant to the process of writing a systematic review.  It would have been much more helpful if lectures and discussions were used as lab time to work on our systematic reviews.
intro to evidenced based medicine is a misnomer - the class is about how to write a systematic review. It's an important skill and I learned a lot, but it was not what I was expecting.

It's not a great course--the systematic review element should just be a small portion of the class rather than the focus of the entire thing. There are many other elements of evidence-based medicine that would have been useful to learn about as well. Also there are such varying levels of experience among the students that it is extremely difficult to have any type of meaningful discussion.
Great

AP- Strengths: My literature searching is much improved, I feel confident in assessing papers for bias, I feel confident that I could competently co-author a systematic review.

Weaknesses: Personally I didn't find the material very exciting or engaging, having said that the skills I have learned will be very valuable additions to my Public Health toolbox.

Sometimes I did the homework stated in the syllabus for the Thursday session, but then it wasn't discussed so I felt my time was a bit wasted. I felt a lot of people in the class weren't that engaged with the material so the class atmosphere wasn't conducive to engaging class discussions. Maybe having a laptop free class would help, or at least have the Tuesday sessions laptop free.

Systematic review and meta-analysis is a hot topic and definitely worth knowing. The course offers a chance to practice it. However, I feel like there are too many readings to be read. It might be better to have, say, one reading per week, as a practice for students to write a summary on their evaluation of biases and such. It doesn't need to be graded, but just having sth. completed might be better.
Could be more organized in terms of assignments

the course material is interesting though it may be too much all at once without applying it in a setting that makes sense for students. the number of students in the course was too large, making discussion classes not as effective since we would be spending too much time discussing one topic and not getting through all content.

Strengths:
-produce a systematic review by the end of the semester
Weakness:
-early in the morning
-unclear about what needs to be turned in (would be nice to have a rubric)
-seemed to apply more to RCTs than observational studies, which would be more useful as an aspiring epidemiologist
I really enjoyed learning about systematic reviews, meta analysis, evidence-based medicine, the importance of each, and how to conduct your own systematic review. Good overview course.

This course is really helpful for you to learn how to conduct systematic review from the beginning. There are also discussion sections every week which can help you solve your questions and confusions for every step of the systematic review.

Great material, super important translation of learning and understanding how biases influence medical research broadly and systematically. Weaknesses were the defined assignments and somewhat-confusing grading rubric.

strengths: very informative, powerpoint slides are full of content, very thorough walkthrough of what it takes to conduct a systematic review
weaknesses: lots and lots of readings per week, maybe spent too many discussion sessions going over classmate's research questions
good class discussions on people's projects. Insane amount of reading. Lectures were very helpful and will prove useful as a guide for me in the future.
Provides valuable information on how to perform a systematic review and meta-analysis

strength: in depth about systemic reviews
weakness: assignments are grouped together and no work in between

Strengths: the skills learned in this class will definitely come to use for a lot of us as we enter our career. The lectures were all very organized.

Weaknesses: while the lectures were great, I felt that Dr. Wang didn't give us much indication of what he was looking for from our midterm and term projects until closer to the deadline. I know many of us felt lost about what was expected from us, especially because we didn't get a run-through on how to navigate the RevMan software until much later in the course.

This course provided me with substantial data analysis and compilation skills along with the ability to construct a systematic review, an invaluable skill as a student and future professional. Attending the lectures was not always very useful, only for key lectures on specific parts of the systematic review process that we would have to carry out. This class would have been much more valuable if we had been constructing each part of our systematic review through the semester with feedback. This would have been a more effective use of our time and would have given us more structural direction.
na
Excellent instructor
Shiyi was a great teacher. He was enthusiastic and always willing to meet with you outside of class.
Thank you for guiding us through the adventure of medical knowledge.
Great instructor. Does a good job at engaging students and soliciting questions. Super accessible and helpful.

very helpful
very available
enthusiastic about the material and engaged with everyone's project individually
Means well but does not explain things well. He did not explain the final assignment at all and left it completely up to us, and that's basically our whole grade.
Great

AP-
Strengths: Really knows his stuff, responds quickly to questions

Weaknesses: Maybe not able to engage 100% of the class, which slowed the pace of the class- we could have spent this time discussing/working on our projects in class to discuss issues related to these
Enthusiastic about the course and created a positive learning environment
the professor is very quick to respond to emails and very willing to meet with students outside of the classroom to discuss course material.
He's incredibly knowledgeable about topics as well as systematic reviews.

Professor Wang is very engaging in class and passionate about this class. His lectures are organized and PPT are helpful. He gave us all very good constructive criticism on our midterm projects. I also appreciate how approachable he is and how he always replies to emails in a timely manner.
Shiyi is really helpful and patient, he gives timely response and instructions through the whole semester.

Shi-Yi is an educator passionate about teaching students and engaging with them - he is nothing short of fantastic. Also willing to give his time, talk through the smallest details, and takes every effort to make an overwhelming subject very approachable.

strengths: gives good examples of key concepts, tries to ensure that everyone understands before moving on, raises many questions about the quality of published papers (good for developing an air of cynicism and skepticism when evaluating strength of evidence)
weaknesses: content may be a little dense sometimes, sometimes we don't get through all of the concepts/slides by the end of class

Professor wang is an expert. He is very knowledgeable in all aspects of systematic reviews and meta analysis and his lectures and readings challenged me to think about how to conduct research, how to write about it, and how to summarize the research of others.

He was very committed and passionate. Was always ready to help.
Once feedback is, that summary information about the course: required submissions , deadlines , guidelines could be consolidated and  placed in a more accessible or intuitive location on the course website.
Great instructor
he gives his best to teach the topic

Dr. Wang is knowledgeable, passionate, and funny. Again, it would be more helpful in the future if he made it clearer what exactly was expected for the midterm and term projects (like an outline) and if helped us navigate through the software earlier on in the semester.
Great instructor! learnt a  lot but need much time to do the final project during the reading week
The instructor was very timely in his responses and feedback and was always willing to help if we were struggling or had any questions.
his response time for emails was amazing and helpful
I would strongly recommend this course
Great course. Every homework and effort done is worthy.
The class is about systematic reviews and meta-analysis, making the class useful if you plan to write one for your thesis

I would recommend this class for anyone who wants to learn how to write and read research papers better. I learned a lot from this course. The systematic review is a lot of work, but it's definitely worth it.
if the student is interested in learning how to write a true systematic review
I would not recommend this course.
Great

AP- I would recommend this course if you want to develop your literature searching skills, and want the skills to be able to write a systematic review as per the Cochrane format. 


If you are not interested in these, I would not recommend it as a 'fill-in' for extra points.
It's a good accomplishment to be able to write a systematic review

the course has room for improvement in terms of managing a larger student body but overall I would recommend the course as it gives the fundamental concepts of evaluating risk. I hope to see more opportunities for students to critically evaluate risk assessment for various types of epidemiological studies.
The course is about writing systematic reviews. I would recommend it because it is important skillset to have.
Good introduction course! Would recommend if you are interested in learning about systematic review, meta-analysis and evidence-based medicine.
I would recommend this course since it can teach you how to conduct systematic review step by step.
If you are interested in research this is essential!

This course focuses on conducting systematic reviews, and walks you through conducting one yourself. REVMAN is a little frustrating to use, but at least it's free? This class also forces you to think critically from multiple perspectives when evaluating the validity of a paper's claims, which I think is an important skill to have, what with all of the misinformation prevalent in mainstream media.
If you are interested in learning about systematic reviews/meta analysis this is a great class. It's labor intensive but the content are high quality and the instructor is very knowledgeable.
I recommend it if you plan on doing writing or learning about systematic reviews and metaanalysis and Cochrane reviews
systematic review and meta-analysis
I would highly recommend this class to any student, especially those who want to strengthen their skills in literature review and writing.

This class was very informative and walked us through the process of writing a systematic review on the topic of our choice. It was definitely a time-consuming course and process, but overall a positive experience.
na
